entry.summary: 在这一点上，AirPods Pro 2 比初代 AirPods Pro 的性能要好于初代 AirPods Pro 与普通 AirPods 的差距。它们不仅仅是无线耳塞——它们是戴在耳朵里的聪明、强大、令人愉悦的计算机。
entry.content:
艾伦·凯 (Alan Kay) 经常引用的众多格言之一是“预测未来的最好方法就是发明它。”我认为，由此得出的一个推论是，欣赏新技术的最佳方式就是回到使用旧版本。

几周前，我步行去费城的约会迟到了。我走路的大多数地方都戴着 AirPods Pro 2，但那天我找不到它们，而且我太晚了，没有时间去寻找。我非常担心整个旅程中我会独自思考，但我的旧第一代 AirPods Pro 放在我的桌子上，而且它们仍然有电量，所以我戴上了它们。

我记得去年，当我第一次从原来的 AirPods Pro 升级到 AirPods Pro 2 时，我就想，新的听起来至少好一点，而且透明度和主动降噪模式都有很大改进。但回到原来的 AirPods Pro，在城市里散步一下午，确实让我们意识到 AirPods Pro 2 的改进有多大。透明模式和降噪效果更好，更引人注目的是，仅音频质量差异就很明显。作为 AirPods Pro 2 的几乎日常用户一年后，我现在发现第一代的音频质量又薄又尖。我对这种差异感到彻底震惊。

上周，苹果宣布对 AirPods Pro 2 进行小幅修改。它们现在在外壳上配备了 USB-C 充电端口（而不是 Lightning），并且对修改后型号的耳塞中的 H2 芯片进行了某种升级Vision Pro 耳机明年发货时可提供低延迟无损音频。

自上周以来，我一直佩戴着一对改进后的 AirPods Pro 2 耳塞，与我用了一年的 iPhone 14 Pro 和其他一些设备配对。显然，我无法评价它们与 Vision Pro 搭配使用时的特殊功能，但就与当前发布的功能相关的所有方面而言，它们比以往任何时候都更好。

截至今天，所有 AirPods 型号均可进行固件更新。对于第二代 AirPods Pro（无论是配备 Lightning 的旧款还是配备 USB-C 的新款），这是一项重大功能更新。调整后的功能包括在打电话或 VoIP 通话期间使用 AirPods 时，通过点击耳塞杆即可将自己静音/取消静音，以及对透明模式和主动降噪模式的改进。但此次更新还带来了两项新功能。

第一个新功能是对话感知，苹果对此进行了如下描述：

当您佩戴 AirPods Pro 并需要与附近的人交谈时，对话感知会自动降低正在播放的音量、增强您面前的声音并减少背景噪音。

启用后（所有 AirPods 选项均位于 iOS 或 MacOS 上的“设置”应用程序中），对话感知实际上是完全自动的。如果您正在听音乐或播客，然后开始与某人交谈，或者其他人刚刚开始与您交谈，它就会开始发挥作用。这非常聪明，但您是否会喜欢它很大程度上取决于您的聆听环境。在我 5 天多的测试中，它在一群人中频繁出现，但没有人与我交谈。有时在城市人行道上，有时在杂货店。在城市环境中，我周围有太多人在说话，而 AirPods 无法知道他们不是在和我说话，因为这个功能总体上不会让人烦恼。但它绝对准确：当我开始说话时，它总是会启动，每次当其他人在我附近说话时，即使他们没有和我说话，我也能分辨出 AirPods 检测到的是谁的声音。将此功能归档为“不适合我个人，但您可能会喜欢它”。

第二个新功能是新的聆听模式：自适应音频。将自适应音频视为透明和主动降噪 (ANC) 之间的中间点。苹果是这样描述的：

由 H2 驱动的 AirPods Pro 现在具有自适应音频功能，可自动优先处理您在世界各地移动时需要注意的声音。通过在需要时将主动降噪与通透模式无缝融合，自适应音频神奇地为任何环境提供正确的声音组合。

请随意对被描述为“神奇”的技术翻白眼（或翻耳朵），但如果我能想出一个更贴切的形容词就该死了。在我（诚然是短暂的）测试时间内，自适应音频似乎更像是透明模式的下一代、甚至更智能的替代品。当我长按任一 AirPod 杆时，我将其设置为仅在两种模式之间切换：自适应模式和 ANC 模式。如果您愿意，您可以添加常规透明度作为您在之间切换的第三种模式，但我还没有找到一个我想要普通透明度而不是自适应的环境。对于城市行人来说，AirPods Pro 2 的透明度非常好；自适应就更好了。它几乎在任何情况下都会自动执行“Dot I Want™”。我听到交通和路人的声音，但即使是吵闹的卡车和公共汽车经过也不会阻止我清楚地听到我正在听的播客（通常）或歌曲（不太常见）。

也许我的使用场景正处于自适应音频所擅长的最佳位置 - 与我的使用场景不利于对话意识相反。但从我使用它们的时间来看，我什至不明白为什么自适应音频不能取代透明度。对我来说，到目前为止，它只是透明度，但更好，有更多的即时动态调整。这是梦幻般的。 （也许电池寿命是保留普通透明模式的原因之一，但我对过去五天的电池寿命的抱怨为零。）

如果您已经使用过 AirPods Pro，您就会知道切换模式时会发出可爱的声音。每种模式都有自己独特的音调，透明和主动降噪的音调听起来像是彼此相反的。当你切换它们时，这些音调会暗示你“打开”和“关闭”你周围的世界。自适应音频有一种新的音调，我将其描述为活泼或快乐。这是一种你可以想象儿童电影中仙女的魔杖发出的声音。对于有趣的模式来说，这是一种有趣的声音，我情不自禁地将这种欢乐的声音视为苹果公司的微妙建议，即对于大多数情况下的大多数人来说，这是“最佳”模式，除了明显的情况下，你想要全面沉浸式主动降噪。

Vision Pro 是苹果首次进军空间计算领域。但 Vision Pro并不是苹果在增强现实领域的第一款产品：AirPods Pro（目前还有 AirPods Max）才是。我们人类是视觉生物，我们自然倾向于将增强现实视为主要的视觉体验，但 AirPods Pro 为您周围的听觉世界提供了令人愉悦且有用的增强功能。从今天开始，自适应音频将其提升到另一个水平。

自适应音频仅适用于 AirPods Pro 2，这意味着如果我再次发现自己出于必要而佩戴旧的第一代 AirPods Pro，我只会更加恼火。在这一点上，AirPods Pro 2 比原来的 AirPods Pro 好得多，就像原来的 AirPods Pro 与原来的非 Pro AirPods 相比一样。它们不仅仅是无线耳塞——它们是戴在耳朵里的聪明、强大、令人愉悦的计算机。我将以一年前写的关于他们的文章作为结束语：

新款 AirPods Pro 是当今苹果公司的最佳单一体现。不是最重要的产品，不是最复杂的产品，也不是最本质的产品。但这体现了苹果正在努力做的一切。它们简单、有用，并且提供大多数人使用和想要的功能。大多数人都使用耳机。很多人每天都在嘈杂的环境中使用它们。对于任何大型包耳式耳机不切实际的场景，AirPods Pro 是世界上最好的耳机。

entry.title: Twitter 竞争对手 T2 更名为“Pebble”
entry.content:
帕雷什·戴夫（Paresh Dave）为《连线》撰稿：

Pebble是一种 Twitter 风格的服务，以前称为 T2 ，今天推出了一种新方法：用户可以跳过“发生了什么？”轻触并单击带有灯泡图标的“想法”选项卡，以查看人工智能生成的帖子或受其过去活动启发的回复列表。在查看其中一条建议后，只需单击一下即可发布该建议。

Pebble 首席执行官 Gabor Cselle 表示，这一功能以及即将推出的生成式人工智能功能将带来更友善、更安全、更有趣的体验。 “我们希望确保您看到精彩的内容，发布精彩的内容，并与社区互动，”他说。

Pebble（此前被称为 T2）与 Bluesky 是一个类似的地方——可能是 Twitter 的直接替代品/替代品，但由于仅限邀请，因此阻碍了增长。通过这次更名，Pebble 对所有人开放，Twitter/X 用户可以在 Pebble 上使用相同的句柄。

我已经拥有一个帐户几个月了，但发现自己很少使用它。如果 Pebble 的状态 ID 是连续的，那么迄今为止该平台上总共只发布了大约 270,000 个帖子。即使与 Bluesky 相比，那里也没有太多动作。一天中实际上只有这么多时间来查看多个非常相似的社交网络。我认为一些类似 Twitter 的服务还有蓬勃发展的空间，但其中六种服务却没有发展空间。

而且，Pebble 团队也做出了与 Post 相同的决定，Post 是另一个可能取代 Twitter 的新贵，但尚未获得关注：他们没有应用程序，只有一个可以像手机上的应用程序一样使用的网站。 [更新： Post 确实只推出了网页版，但现在有了应用程序。] 在过去十年中，是否有哪个成功的社交网络没有推出 iOS 应用程序？ Bluesky 的应用程序不是很好，但它比 PWA 更好，我想知道有多少普通人不信任不是来自 App Store 或 Google Play 的应用程序。而且，抛开信任不谈，我想知道有多少人知道如何将 PWA 添加到他们的主屏幕上。

我认为，这很能说明问题，Meta仅将 Threads 作为 iOS 和 Android 的本机应用程序推出，甚至网络应用程序版本也在一个月后推出。如果他们以网络优先的方式推出，那么高调的 Threads 发布规模将会小得多。

entry.title: Apple 不再销售 MagSafe 电池组和 MagSafe Duo 折叠充电器
entry.content:

尽管这些配件在技术上已因今天的公告而过时，但如果需要，您仍然可以在亚马逊等网站上购买它们（ MagSafe 电池组和MagSafe Duo 充电器），售完即止。

Duo Charger 是一个很好的概念，特别是对于旅行来说，但现代 iPhone 太大了，而且它不支持最近 Apple Watch 的新型高速充电。

但 MagSafe 电池组是一款非常棒的产品，我很遗憾看到它消失了，而且可能仍然是您想要购买的东西，售完即止。随身携带它，您可以使用 USB-C 数据线（插入手机）或Lightning 数据线（插入电池组）为新 iPhone 15 充电。无论哪种方式，其他设备都将通过双向 MagSafe 连接进行充电。

在 MagSafe 电池组推出之前，Apple 曾为一些老款 iPhone 销售过一系列电池盒。你还记得它们—— 它们看起来有点奇怪，因为电池部分就像怀孕的驼峰。苹果从未在发布相应 iPhone 的同时发布过电池盒。他们会在 9 月份发布 iPhone，然后在两个月后悄悄发布电池组。我一直怀疑这是故意的——苹果不想在新 iPhone 发布的同时发布外接电池组或外壳，以避免新 iPhone 的一些新闻报道暗示它们需要外接电池。电池组，因为内置电池电量不足。

因此，也许苹果公司已经停止销售 MagSafe 电池组了。但是，即使他们正在开发新的 USB-C 版本，我对它上周没有发布一点也不感到惊讶。让我们等待11月吧。我希望他们确实发布一款，因为苹果的 MagSafe 电池组比我尝试过的第三方电池组（包括 Anker 的两个不错的电池组）要好得多。苹果公司不是最大的，但它是最好的，因为它是最聪明的。连接时它会与 iPhone 进行智能协商，并且不会浪费电量为 iPhone 充电超过 80% 左右。仅通过热量就可以感受到效率的差异。第三方感应电池组会变得相当热；苹果的没有。另外，第三方的似乎都是“磁性的”，而不是官方的“MagSafe”——苹果的棒也更好。

entry.title: 为什么 iPhone 15 Pro 感觉更轻
entry.content:
德朗博士：

最后，杰森·斯内尔 (Jason Snell) 在上手区域使用 15 Pro 时，他对 15 Pro 的轻盈程度感到惊讶。他不仅在Macworld 文章中提到了这一点，还在升级主题演讲后的节目中提到了这一点。你不会想到从 14 Pro 的 206 克到 15 Pro 的 187 克的变化会那么明显，但 Greg Joswiak 在主题演讲中提到了这一点，Jason 也证实了这一点。怎么可能？

一个答案是，人们只是比我们想象的更加敏感。体重下降 9% 至 10% 对我们的大脑来说似乎很小，但对我们的手来说却是很大的重量。但因为它允许我进行一些简单的计算，所以我决定研究另一种可能性。

您操纵手机的能力主要取决于其质量，但也取决于其惯性矩。由于从不锈钢切换到钛时质量的减少几乎完全发生在手机的周边，因此与均匀减少质量相比，转动惯量应该减少更多。

当然，Drang 展示了他的作品。毫无疑问，我认为这是有道理的：新款 iPhone Pro 给人的感觉比单纯减轻重量所暗示的还要轻。

周二的“Wonderlust”事件基本上是可以预见的吗？是的。这是否意味着它很无聊？对于某些人来说，是的。但对于大多数人来说，这是今年最大的科技新闻事件，就像每年晚些时候的苹果 iPhone 发布会一样。

从历史上看，这既奇怪又新鲜——对于许多技术爱好者来说，这令人失望。传统上，科技公司的运作方式是，公司的命运在每个十年中都会起伏不定。而大型新的“年度科技产品”不仅每隔几年就会从一家公司更换到另一家公司，而且还会在不同的产品类别中发生变化。从 PC 到 PDA，从数码相机到 iPod。 1

但在过去的十年里，整个科技界最盛大的事件是苹果公司每年推出的新款 iPhone。你可能会说这不应该是今年最大的事件，但从媒体报道的角度来看，它客观上确实如此。我不确定我认识的人是否至少不知道苹果公司本周刚刚发布了新款 iPhone。仅此一点就很了不起。这很像超级碗，它通常甚至不是一年中最好的橄榄球比赛，更不用说体育赛事了，但无可否认是最大的。即使不看超级碗的人也知道超级碗何时举行。但即使是超级碗也只是美国的现象——iPhone赛事是全球性的，更像是世界杯或奥运会，但世界杯和奥运会每四年才举办一次。

就像超级碗吸引了体育新闻界以外的媒体关注一样，iPhone 事件也吸引了科技界以外的媒体报道。亲自参加 iPhone 活动会有一种完全不同且独特的氛围。从媒体参加者的角度来看，这些 iPhone 活动充斥着一种嗡嗡声、一种忙碌感和期待感，最重要的是，一种明显的、难以想象的高风险感弥漫在其中。你可以说这些事件很无聊，因为它们是可以预测的，但苹果需要每一代 iPhone 都成为热门产品，媒体知道这一点，而且媒体总是在寻找一个失误来详细说明，比如天线门的无意义争议早在 2010 年，iPhone 4 就出现了。2铁杆体育迷对围绕超级碗的所有非体育方面感到恼火，例如将注意力集中在中场音乐会表演者甚至电视广告上。铁杆科技迷同样对“你去过哪个星球？”感到恼火。我们其他人都知道新 iPhone 的细节将会像去年一样出现。证据 A：本周的主流新闻报道完全以从 Lightning 到 USB-C 的转换为主导。

史蒂夫·乔布斯剧院是一个美妙的地方，对我来说，这些 iPhone 活动是令人着迷的体验。 （我周二拍摄了一段视频，试图捕捉主题演讲后动手区域的布局和体验。）但从“我想知道苹果今天要宣布什么”的意义上来说，它们一点也不有趣。 ”这更像是对苹果如何选择如何构建我们都知道即将发布的公告的浓厚兴趣。将新款 iPhone 的推出与新款 Apple Watch 的推出以及今年更新的 AirPods Pro 结合起来，是完美但乏味的。 3

但不可否认这是事实。苹果有一个公式，而且这个公式仍然有效。

环境

主题演讲中由奥克塔维亚·斯宾塞饰演的 20 分钟“大自然”小品遭到了广泛批评。我确实认为它持续得太长了——整个片段（草图加细节）实际上只有 10 分钟长，而不是 20 分钟。但似乎每个人，包括我，都觉得它持续了 20 分钟，这从来都不是一个好兆头。

但我明白了。

传达的信息是：当今大多数公司都对其未来的环境影响做出承诺。但苹果不仅仅只是做出承诺。他们在这方面取得了真正伟大的成就。现在你可以购买整块碳中和的 Apple Watch，这可不是开玩笑。苹果公司在其使用的材料、在世界各地运输产品的方式、包装方式、自己发电的方式等方面都做出了巨大的改变。他们想要明确的是，整个领域是公司的最高优先事项之一，真正是其制度道德指南针的一部分，对苹果所做的一切都有影响，而且他们已经取得了伟大的成就。大多数其他公司基本上只是在这些东西上进行绿色清洗。

但苹果如何证明这一点呢？他们不能只是把丽莎·杰克逊放在那里，然后指责其他公司是企业骗子，尽管它们确实是骗子。喜剧就是答案。喜剧可以让你说出原本无法说的话。讽刺、戏仿和闹剧都是传达严肃论点的极具欺骗性的有力方式。

这一段的问题很简单，就是不够有趣。这是一个很棒的概念，但结果还算可以。它需要更多 Tina Fey 30 Rock 的节奏——更有趣的笑话和更多的笑话。 （苹果公司是否因为 WGA 对此的罢工而受到阻碍？我不禁想知道是否如此。这个短剧看起来不错——只是文字感觉软弱无力。）

这一领域的一个里程碑式的变化是苹果公司宣称其产品全部采用皮革制成。不再有 iPhone 皮革保护壳、皮革表带——包括爱马仕的皮革表带。他们利润丰厚的合作关系仍在继续，但仅限于织物和橡胶表带。 （除非你从 Hermès 自己购买 Apple Watch。）Apple 已经用一种名为 FineWoven 的新材料取代了自己的皮革 iPhone 保护壳和表带。我花了一些时间在动手区摆弄新的手机壳和表带，我喜欢 FineWoven 材料。主题演讲仅强调了相对于皮革的道德角度：碳影响和动物权利。但至少对于 iPhone 手机壳来说，我认为 FineWoven 比旧的皮革手机壳要好得多。我个人喜欢漂亮的皮革制品，但我总觉得苹果用来生产 iPhone 保护壳的皮革充其量只是还可以。特别是，我认为它的耐候性不太好，而且我从来都不是 iPhone 保护壳的重度用户，通常我的手机壳都是不带保护壳的。抛开所有道德问题，假装苹果仍在销售皮革 iPhone 保护壳和这些新的 FineWoven 保护壳，我宁愿购买 FineWoven 保护壳。根据我的实践经验，我并不完全相信 FineWoven Apple Watch 表带，但最坏的情况是，它们看起来相当不错。 （苹果的皮革表带比爱马仕的便宜，但也明显不如爱马仕的好。）

新箱子的预订已经开始到货，人们对新材料的反应不一。我很好奇它会随着时间的推移而变得如何，尤其是表带，但我的第一印象是，这是对苹果皮革产品的质量升级，而不仅仅是道德方面的升级。我不认为 FineWoven 材料比优质皮革更好，但我确实认为它比苹果制造的皮革 iPhone 保护壳更好，也许与他们自己以前的皮革表带相当。但它不是的一件事是人造皮革。如果 Jony Ive 还在苹果，他可能会这样描述它：毫无疑问，它是一种面料。

普通 iPhone 15

iPhone 15（非 Pro 版）似乎正是我们所希望的：实际上，iPhone 14 Pro 没有长焦第三个摄像头。

这让我对这些颜色吹毛求疵，在我看来，这些颜色平淡无奇，除了黑色之外，它和往常一样，确实是一种非常深的黑色。颜色趋势随季节变化，我可能应该更相信苹果的设计师而不是我自己来保持潮流的领先地位，但是伙计，这个阵容看起来平淡无奇。也许浅色调今年会“流行”，但我非常怀疑今后是否有人会说“还记得 iPhone 15 的颜色有多棒吗？”与我们对初代 iMac 的普遍喜爱进行比较和对比。

今年的新功能：普通版 iPhone 15 采用磨砂玻璃后背；迄今为止，非专业型号是光面的，专业型号是磨砂/哑光的。第一次，Pro 版和非Pro 版 iPhone 的手感非常相似：拉丝金属侧面、磨砂玻璃背面、非常相似的尺寸，以及相似的重量。

iPhone 15 显示屏更亮，与 15 Pro 型号的显示屏具有相同的对比度和最大亮度。不过，非专业版 iPhone 15 机型缺少：ProMotion 动态刷新率和常亮显示模式。反过来，缺乏常亮显示屏意味着 iOS 17 中的新待机功能对于 Pro 机型来说更加有用。对于非专业版 iPhone 15，“待机”只会显示，直到显示超时并进入睡眠状态；对于 iPhone Pro（包括去年的 14 Pro 型号），待机功能始终处于开启状态。

iPhone 15 Pro

Pro 型号的颜色选择符合最新趋势：黑色（实际上更像是深灰色）、白色和年度颜色。去年 iPhone 14 Pro 的颜色是紫色。今年是蓝色，而且是漂亮但相当深的蓝色。有趣的是，还有“天然钛”，这并不是真正的天然，而是通过 PVD ​​色调实现的，看起来就像人们认为的钛一样，这为苹果最近对颜色没有太多乐趣的论点增添了更多的依据。自然看起来像。就其本身而言，“天然钛”看起来像中性拉丝金属色调。然而，与白色的 iPhone 15 Pro 放在一起，你可以看到苹果的“天然钛金属”更温暖。它看起来并不全是金色，但有一点点黄色。天然钛合金车型的整体效果是“高级灰色”，有点像经典的阿斯顿·马丁 DB5的氛围。我认为，白色的可以完全被描述为“银色”——色温真正中性，而且看起来更闪亮。 iPhone 15 Pro 上的自然色和白色钛金属都无法与 Apple Watch Ultra 的钛金属机身相匹配，但自然色更接近。

与后 iPhone-X 时代的所有不锈钢 iPhone 相比，15 Pro 和 Pro Max 的手感要轻得多。假设它们在现实世界的使用中证明是耐用的，那么仅从重量来看，从抛光不锈钢到钛的转变就是一个巨大的胜利。但我也更喜欢它的外观和感觉——略带纹理，而不是高度抛光。我认为我的 iPhone 是一个工具，而不是珠宝；抛光表面似乎不太合适，就像钢质 Apple Watch 那样。

框架的圆形边缘——这一设计变化也出现在铝制非专业型号中——也是一个胜利。这感觉像是 iPhone X/XS/11 的完全圆形侧面和 iPhone 12/13/14 的平坦锐边侧面之间的最佳中间地带。预计这种外形尺寸也会在三代中保持稳定——苹果是一家模式公司。

操作按钮看起来很棒。开箱即用，它默认充当静音切换开关，但选择其他操作很容易（并且可以说很有趣）。内置操作包括：手电筒、启动相机应用程序、在语音备忘录中开始录音和放大镜。但是，当您分配它来执行快捷方式工作流程时，选项实际上是无限的。

摄影和 GPU

从表面上看，相机功能和 GPU 规格似乎并不相关，但它们有一个主题相似之处：苹果在这两个领域都处于行业最先进的地位。当然，iPhone 相机并不落后于最先进的手机摄影技术——它们可能是最好的，而且无可否认是最好的。但它们并不是世界上最好的相机，句号。苹果希望他们能够做到这一点，并且年复一年地不懈追求这一目标。虽然 Apple Silicon GPU 无可否认地在手机领域处于市场领先地位，但它们在 PC 领域也无可否认地处于市场领先地位，而 Nvidia 在 PC 领域占据着至高无上的地位。我坚信，苹果希望用 GPU 对付 Nvidia，就像他们用 CPU 对付英特尔一样——在纯粹性能上赶上或超越他们，并在每瓦性能上彻底击败他们。

在摄影方面，周二宣布了两项主要新功能。第一个是新一代人像摄影，在将图像作为常规静止图像拍摄后，可以将人像模式应用到图像上。自从肖像模式首次亮相以来，我就一直想要这个功能。捕捉时，你不需要做任何该死的事情。您只需构图并按下快门即可。没有切换模式。但设备上的机器学习会当场决定人像模式是否可以改善图像（只有当拍摄对象是人、狗或猫时才会自动发生），但你可以启用它、禁用它，并将其调整为帖子中您的心满意足。

其次是 iPhone 15 Pro 机型捕捉空间视频的能力。我整个夏天就猜测，如果苹果今年能够为 iPhone 推出这款产品，那就太酷了，他们也做到了。显然，观看空间视频的最佳方式是使用 Vision 耳机，但捕捉空间视频的最佳方式是使用 iPhone，尤其是根据一句古老的格言，最好的相机是随身携带的相机。我认为 iPhone 最终将能够捕捉空间视频记忆，但对我来说，这是苹果公司今年实现的卓越运营和跨设备协作的标志，iPhone 的出货量将比第一款提前几个月——一代 Vision Pro。 （使用 iPhone 15 Pro 拍摄空间视频的功能尚不可用 - 它“将在今年晚些时候推出”。并且动手区域单元没有该功能，也没有预加载任何示例空间视频。因此，唯一的方法是使用 iPhone 15 Pro 拍摄空间视频。我们对该功能的了解是在主题演讲中广播的内容。）

关于A17 Pro，我们先从名字开始。苹果公司在许多不同的产品上以多种不同的方式使用“pro”，但他们非常一致的一件事是“Pro”产品是唯一具有“pro”组件或功能的产品。 （请注意，例如，ProMotion 动态刷新率仅适用于 iPhone Pro、iPad Pro 和 MacBook Pro。）因此，我认为苹果再次调整了其双管齐下的年度 iPhone 战略：我打赌明年的 iPhone 16 和16 Plus 将配备 A17 SoC，但我也打赌该芯片不会是 A17 Pro。也许那将是A17“Bionic”，也许只是没有形容词的“A17”，但我不认为iPhone 15 Pro中搭载的A17 Pro。

明年的非专业版 A17 可能会有什么不同？我怀疑 GPU 可能不会那么强大（也许，通过分箱，它将提供 5 个核心而不是 6 个），而且我怀疑它可能有 6 GB RAM（如 A16 Bionic 芯片），而不是 8 GB RAM。 A17 Pro。

但天哪，A17 Pro 的 GPU 好像多强啊。硬件加速光线追踪是一件大事，也是苹果 M 系列芯片（没有）与 Nvidia 和 AMD 的高端 PC GPU（有）之间的主要区别因素。显然，这款新 GPU 不仅是 A17 Pro 的最大亮点，也将成为 Mac 和 iPad（以及最终的 Vision 耳机）M3 系列芯片的最大亮点。 A系列芯片一直拥有世界一流的手机GPU，但苹果也试图缩小PC端的高端GPU差距。

但当？ A17 Pro 实际上是台积电下一代 3nm 制造工艺的发布。有消息称，苹果已经确保了台积电明年 90-95% 的 3nm 产量，而且听起来台积电的产量可能无法满足 iPhone 15 Pro 的需求——iPhone 15 Pro 型号可能会缺货几个月，来。这是苹果公司双管齐下的年度 iPhone 战略的一个方面，我上周没有提到。我认为非 Pro 版 iPhone 15 机型甚至不可能使用 A17 芯片，因为仅为 Pro 版机型生产 A17 芯片就已经够麻烦了。

因此，仅根据台积电的 3nm 生产能力，我预计今年不会看到 M3 Mac 或 iPad，也许要到明年中旬才会出现。还要记住，15 英寸 M2 MacBook Air 三个月前刚刚推出。对我来说，这表明 M2 至少在明年之前仍将保持“流行”。我认为，希望今年推出新款 M3 MacBook Air 的人们可能会失望。

它说明了 iPhone 在苹果产品线中的卓越地位——这种卓越地位合理地建立在广泛的受欢迎程度和盈利能力之上——它比任何其他产品都早早地获得了最尖端的芯片。

似乎每家公司都在争先恐后地在人工智能淘金热中占据一席之地—— 克罗格的首席执行官承诺将法学硕士带入乳制品领域。一线工作人员也在效仿——尝试人工智能，以便他们可以更快地工作并做得更多。

自 ChatGPT 推出以来的短短几个月内，市场上已经出现了数百种人工智能驱动的工具。但是，虽然基于人工智能的工具具有真正有用的应用程序，但它们也带来了严重的安全风险。不幸的是，大多数公司仍然没有拿出管理这些风险的政策。在缺乏关于负责任的人工智能使用的明确指导的情况下，员工会漫不经心地将敏感数据交给不值得信赖的工具。

基于人工智能的浏览器扩展最清楚地说明了这一现象。 Chrome 商店中充斥着（声称）利用 ChatGPT 执行各种任务的扩展：发送电子邮件、设计图形、转录会议和编写代码。但这些工具容易出现至少三种类型的风险。

  1. 恶意软件：安全研究人员不断发现窃取用户数据的基于人工智能的扩展。这些扩展程序利用了用户对大型科技平台的信任（“如果 Google 允许它出现在 Chrome 商店中，那不会有危险！”），而且它们通常通过连接 ChatGPT 等人的 API 来发挥作用。
  2. 数据治理：包括苹果和威瑞森在内的公司已禁止其员工使用法学硕士，因为这些产品很少能保证用户的输入不会被用作培训数据。
  3. 即时注入攻击：在这种鲜为人知但可能无法解决的攻击中，网页上的隐藏文本指示人工智能工具执行恶意操作，例如窃取数据，然后删除记录。

到目前为止，大多数公司都被人工智能打了个措手不及，但这些风险太严重了，不容忽视。

在 Kolide，我们采用两部分方法来管理人工智能的使用。

  1. 以团队形式起草人工智能政策。我们不想完全禁止我们的团队使用人工智能，我们只是想安全地使用它。因此，我们的第一步是与多个团队的代表会面，了解他们从基于人工智能的工具中获得了什么，以及我们如何为他们提供不暴露关键数据或基础设施的安全选项。
  2. 使用 Kolide 阻止恶意工具。 Kolide 让 IT 和安全团队编写检测设备合规性问题的检查，我们已经开始为基于人工智能的恶意（或可疑）工具创建检查。现在，如果员工不小心下载了恶意软件，他们将无法登录我们的云应用程序，直到他们将其删除。

每家公司都必须根据自己独特的需求和关注点制定政策，但重要的是现在就开始。在人工智能卷走你公司的数据之前，我们还有时间抓住它的控制权。

entry.summary: 在运动方面，Pro型号是进攻，非Pro型号是防守。他们说，赢得冠军的是防守。
entry.content:
2017 年， iPhone X标志着 iPhone 历史上一个明显的转折点：从最初的 Home 键系统界面（带有 Touch ID）切换到带有 Face ID 的“全屏”界面。但这也标志着苹果年度 iPhone 硬件战略的一个广泛误解/低估（尽管我很痛苦地指出，并非全部）的变化。 2017 年，苹果开始每年推出两款完全不同级别的新 iPhone，而不是只推出一款新 iPhone。一位“专业”，一位“常规”：

专业版常规的
2017年X/A11 8 / A11
2018年XS/A12 XR/A12
2019年11 Pro/A13 11 / A13
2020年12 Pro/A14 12 / A14
2021年13 Pro / A15 13 / A15
2022年14 Pro / A16 14 / A15
2023年15 Pro/A17 15 / A16

（对于今年的模型，最后一行在撰写本文时是推测性的，但似乎有可能。）

该表并未考虑同一级别（Mini / Max / Plus）内的不同尺寸，但这些实际上只是相同基本 iPhone 的不同尺寸。真正的区别在于专业型号和非专业型号之间。苹果直到 2019 年 iPhone 11 才开始将 iPhone 命名为“Pro”，但实际上，他们在 2017 年通过 X 开始了这一“专业”级别。

每个人都对这一策略感到不满的是，专业型号的价格更高。当然是。但许多人忽视了苹果战略的一些方面。最重要的是，iPhone Pro 机型的生产期限仅为一年。如果这种模式成立，那么下周，iPhone 14 Pro和Pro Max将停止生产，并在产品线中被新的15 Pro机型取代。然而，非专业版 iPhone 的生产时间至少还要延长两年，价格每年下降 100 美元。我觉得这很有趣，但很少有人注意到。最昂贵、最先进、而且我认为最难制造的 iPhone 只生产一年。这是 iPhone X 之前的一种全新策略，当时每年只有一款新的旗舰 iPhone（尽管在 iPhone 6-6S-7 年间有两种尺寸），而且大多数 iPhone 都以降价形式保留在产品阵容中。未来几年。

因此，虽然有报道称去年的 iPhone 14 Plus 销量不是特别好，但这并不意味着它是失败的，甚至不意味着苹果预计它去年的销量会那么好。对我来说，非专业 iPhone 的主力年份是产品线的第二年和第三年，那时它们的价格会下降。人们购买较便宜的 iPhone 但想要大屏幕的人以前从未有过选择：现在已经上市一年的 iPhone 14 Plus 就是这样的选择。

去年一个引人注目的变化是，非专业版 iPhone 14 机型自 2021 年起仍采用 A15 芯片。一个不太引人注目的变化是，iPhone 14 与 iPhone 13 在内部有很大不同，尽管两者都使用 A15 芯片。相同的A15芯片。 iFixit 将 iPhone 14（非专业型号）描述为苹果有史以来最容易维修的 iPhone。芯片保持不变，但内部设计完全不同，而且更好。 iPhone 14 的设计本应在未来几年内继续生产。

明天我们不知道这种更可修复、更易于访问的系统架构是否会在 iPhone 15 上重复，但我怀疑它会的。无论如何，常规的 iPhone 15 机型将不仅仅是 iPhone 14 Pro 机型重新包装为铝制框架而不是不锈钢。在我看来，苹果已经实现的战略是：

  • 专业机型：尖端芯片、摄像头、材料；生产期限仅为一年。
  • 非专业型号：使用一年前的SoC和旧相机系统的精致架构；将在发布年份后生产 2-3 年。

iPhone Pro 更令人兴奋，但非 Pro iPhone 对于该产品线乃至整个 iPhone 生态系统至关重要。在运动方面，Pro型号是进攻，非Pro型号是防守。他们说，进攻赢得荣耀，但防守才能赢得冠军。

entry.title: ★ 苹果双管齐下的年度 iPhone 战略
至少“疯狂”这个词很合适
entry.content:
CNBC 摘录了沃尔特·艾萨克森 (Walter Isaacson) 的埃隆·马斯克 (Elon Musk)的另一段摘录，讲述了马斯克和他的表兄弟将数千台服务器从萨克拉门托的一个数据中心迁移到波特兰的另一个数据中心的故事：

“你必须聘请承包商来抬起地板，”亚历克斯说。 “它们需要用吸盘来举起。”他说，另一组承包商必须进入地板下方并断开电缆和地震杆。

马斯克转向他的保安，要求借用他的小刀。使用它，他能够抬起地板上的一个通风口，这使他能够撬开地板面板。然后他自己爬到服务器地板下，用刀撬开电气柜，拔掉服务器插头，然后等着看会发生什么。什么都没有爆炸。服务器已准备好移动。

“嗯，这看起来并不难，”他说道，乌兹别克人亚历克斯和其他人都盯着看。马斯克对此非常兴奋。他大声笑着说，这就像翻拍的《碟中谍》萨克拉门托版。

一切都是一堆令人厌恶的事情，直到它变成了令人厌恶的事情：

服务器上有用户数据，詹姆斯最初并没有意识到，出于隐私原因，它们应该在移动之前被清除干净。 “当我们了解到这一点时，服务器已经被拔掉并推出，因此我们无法将它们回滚，插入，然后擦除它们，”他说。另外，擦除软件无法运行。 “妈的，我们该怎么办？”他问。埃隆建议他们锁定卡车并跟踪它们。

因此，詹姆斯派人去家得宝购买大挂锁，然后他们将电子表格上的密码发送到波特兰，以便在那里打开卡车。 “我不敢相信它有效，”詹姆斯说。 “他们都安全抵达波特兰。”

在某种程度上，深刻的紧迫感对领导者是有益的。尽管 CNBC 有这样的框架，但马斯克显然已经远远超出了这一点。整个努力是荒谬且不必要的鲁莽。除了侵犯隐私之外，不顾 Twitter 基础设施团队的直接建议将这些服务器从萨克拉门托撤出，还直接导致用户数月的不稳定。

中国计划将敏感部门使用 iPhone 的禁令扩大到政府支持的机构和国有企业，这表明苹果公司在其最大的国外市场和全球生产基地面临着越来越大的挑战。

[ Inside Baseball Interpolation: I have often mentioned here that Bloomberg, as a news organization, is uniquely fanatical about scoops — being the first to break news, and in particular, market-moving news . And they expect credit for their scoops when the news is re-reported elsewhere. So trust me, it pains them to credit the Journal for this scoop. If Beijing goes ahead, the unprecedented blockade will be the culmination of a yearslong effort to root out foreign technology use in sensitive environments, coinciding with Beijing's effort to reduce its reliance on American software and circuitry.

This gets to the nut of my intense curiosity regarding this edict. How much of it is nationalism — the CCP turning up the dial on the inherently jingoist mindset of a police state — and how much of it, if any, is about the fact that iPhones are secure, and their security is outside the reach of the CCP? The Chinese government surely wants to surveil what government employees do on their phones, and iPhones make that harder.

Lastly, where does Apple's unique relationship with the Chinese government play into this? Apple remains dependent upon China for manufacturing, the iPhone in particular. They make some iPhones elsewhere , but the overwhelming majority are assembled in China, and there's no other supply chain on earth that can replace it today. That's a terrible starting point for any negotiation. But: China gets a lot from Apple. Over the course of my lifetime, China has been fighting to change the perception of what “Made in China” stands for. It's always meant cheap. It used to also imply shoddy. Apple is the feather in China's cap. iPhones aren't just the nicest phones in the world — they're arguably the nicest and most complex mass-produced consumer products in any category. And they are made almost exclusively in China.

The Chinese government surely bristles at the pariah status of Huawei globally , but there's no plausible scenario where any Chinese company achieves the sort of prestige Apple has. Huawei phones, at best , are third-rate, and everyone knows it, including everyone in China. 2 If China maintains its symbiotic relationship with Apple, China will remain firmly associated with the most prestigious technology brand in the world. If not, and Apple migrates its primary manufacturing elsewhere, China again drops to being associated only with second- and third-rate products. Even worse, the best company — in that scenario — would have chosen to part with China. China gains enormous prestige from Apple; Apple takes a reputational hit from its reliance upon a brutal human-rights-violating communist dictatorship.

Perhaps China feels free to antagonize Apple out of the belief that Apple cannot eliminate its dependence upon Chinese manufacturing. But even if that's true, the message to other companies (say, carmakers) eyeing a move to Chinese assembly would be this: once you grow dependent upon China we'll screw you like we screwed Apple. China's intended message to the world isn't merely that they're the most capable nation for manufacturing, it's that they're also a trustworthy and dependable partner.

This sandbagging of Apple regarding iPhone usage by government employees says the opposite: that China cannot be trusted as a partner.

So here's how I tally the detente. If Apple can ease away from its dependence upon China for manufacturing, they might . But the risk is that doing so will upset the Xi Jinping regime and Apple will suffer in consumer product sales within China. (Perhaps that's what we're seeing now?)

If Apple does ease away from China, though, who can China replace them with? Who could they tout as a world-class technology company that relies upon China for manufacturing? Second place is so far behind Apple you can't see it.

entry.title: The Indiana Pi Bill
entry.content:
Wikipedia:

The Indiana Pi Bill is the popular name for bill #246 of the 1897 sitting of the Indiana General Assembly, one of the most notorious attempts to establish mathematical truth by legislative fiat. Despite its name, the main result claimed by the bill is a method to square the circle, although it does imply various incorrect values of the mathematical constant π, the ratio of the circumference of a circle to its diameter. The bill, written by a physician who was an amateur mathematician, never became law due to the intervention of Prof. CA Waldo of Purdue University, who happened to be present in the legislature on the day it went up for a vote.

Here's a good summary (from modern day Purdue professor Edray Goins) of how this kook Edwin Goodwin arrived at π = 3.2.

I was reminded of this laughable legislation * by a friend commenting on the UK abandoning its foolhardy attempt to mandate the inspection of impossible-to-inspect end-to-end messaging. E2EE communication cannot be “scanned” for child pornography while remaining secure for all other purposes, but it would be nice if it could. Pi is not 3.2 and a circle cannot be squared, but it would nice if it were so. The UK's legislation is every bit as much ignorant wishful thinking as Indiana's was over a century ago.

That Indiana bill was not defeated, however — it was apparently merely shelved. The UK, likewise, has not repealed the law granting them the power to effectively ban end-to-end encryption — they've merely declared that they will not use it — yet. That's dangerous. This law should be rescinded, not ignored.

* From Waldo's own account of the saga comes this gem of a quote (written in the third person), regarding an offer to be introduced to Goodwin: “A member then showed the writer a copy of the bill just passed and asked him if he would like an introduction to the learned doctor, its author. He declined the courtesy with thanks remarking that he was acquainted with as many crazy people as he cared to know.”

Amen, Dr. Waldo.

entry.title: Rotten Tomatoes Is Rotten
entry.content:
Lane Brown, writing for Vulture:

But despite Rotten Tomatoes's reputed importance, it's worth a reminder: Its math stinks. Scores are calculated by classifying each review as either positive or negative and then dividing the number of positives by the total. That's the whole formula . Every review carries the same weight whether it runs in a major newspaper or a Substack with a dozen subscribers.

If a review straddles positive and negative, too bad. “I read some reviews of my own films where the writer might say that he doesn't think that I pull something off, but, boy, is it interesting in the way that I don't pull it off,” says Schrader, a former critic. “To me, that's a good review, but it would count as negative on Rotten Tomatoes.” [...]

Another problem — and where the trickery often begins — is that Rotten Tomatoes scores are posted after a movie receives only a handful of reviews, sometimes as few as five, even if those reviews may be an unrepresentative sample. This is sort of like a cable-news network declaring an Election Night winner after a single county reports its results. But studios see it as a feature, since, with a little elbow grease, they can sometimes fool people into believing a movie is better than it is.

Brown also uncovers implicit payola, with a Hollywood PR firm paying small-time critics tracked by Rotten Tomatoes $50 (fifty measly bucks!) for positive reviews. My whole family has been growing ever more skeptical of Rotten Tomatoes scores for years, but we reached a breaking point earlier this year when we rented M3gan , which we all found to be a shitty movie, but scored a 93 from Rotten Tomatoes . (It has a “generally favorable” 72 from Metacritic .)

entry.title: UK Abandons, for Now, Legislation That Would Have Banned End-to-End Encryption
entry.content:
Cristina Criddle, Anna Gross, and John Aglionby, reporting from London for The Financial Times ( paywall-circumventing Twitter link ):

The UK government has conceded it will not use controversial powers in the online safety bill to scan messaging apps for harmful content until it is “technically feasible” to do so, postponing measures that critics say threaten users' privacy.

In a statement to the House of Lords on Wednesday afternoon, junior arts and heritage minister Lord Stephen Parkinson sought to mark an eleventh-hour effort to end a stand-off with tech companies, including WhatsApp, that have threatened to pull their services from the UK over what they claimed was an intolerable threat to millions of users' privacy and security.

Parkinson said that Ofcom, the tech regulator, would only require companies to scan their networks when a technology is developed that is capable of doing so. Many security experts believe it could be years before any such technology is developed, if ever.

No, Thursday's out. How about never — is never good for you ?

WhatsApp, owned by Facebook's parent Meta, and Signal, another popular encrypted messaging app, are among those that have threatened to exit the UK market should they be ordered to weaken encryption, a widely used security technology that allows only the sender and recipient of messages to view a message's contents. [...]

Officials have privately acknowledged to tech companies that there is no current technology able to scan end-to-end encrypted messages that would not also undermine users' privacy, according to several people briefed on the government's thinking.

This isn't the worst reporting on encryption and lawmakers' fantasies about “backdoors only accessible by the good guys”, but it's fundamentally misleading. End-to-end encryption's meaning is right there in its name. There's no dial that can be adjusted from “weak” to “strong”. There's no option for content inspection between end points. It's not about choosing not to allow eavesdroppers, it's about implementing protocols where it's technically impossible to inspect content between sender and receiver.

The actual math is far more complex, but ultimately this boils down to the UK acknowledging that 2 + 2 can only equal 4.

entry.title: Horace Dediu: 'The Value of a Customer'
entry.content:
Horace Dediu, writing at the newly refreshed Asymco:

So the picture becomes clearer. The iPhone customer is 7.4 times more valuable than the Android customer. This is more impressive than the 4× rule I had 10 years ago. The reasons are mainly that my anecdotes were from developers who sold products in the US or EU whereas expansion of smartphones to 7 billion global users has drawn in more lower spending customers.

But Apple's base has also grown to over 1 billion users (650 million store users). This highlights that Apple has effectively grown and discriminated customers effectively. It obtained not just 1 billion customers but the best 1 billion customers.

How to discriminate effectively is the holy grail of marketing. The naïve approach is to keep prices high. But that usually only results in a “luxury” branding and a small base that tends not to grow. The alternative “premium” approach is to offer functionality and multiple tiers and distribution options and financing and merchandising. There is no simple formula.

I really enjoyed this piece, but I will quibble with “There is no simple formula”. It's the execution that is difficult and complex. But at a high level the formula Apple has applied to make the iPhone (and iPad) the unprecedented success that they are is remarkably simple.

First, make something people care deeply about. Computers are the biggest advance in human society since the industrial revolution; revolution is a strong word but it applied then and applies again today. People care about their computers and what they do on their computers very much, and they care most about the most personal of personal computers: their phones. They use them for communication, photography, entertainment (music and video), games, and more. They carry them almost everywhere they go, all day every day, and sleep next to them.

Second, make the best version of that thing people care deeply about. The people who care the most will perceive the superiority of your product, and gladly — not begrudgingly — pay a premium for it.

Third, keep iterating, tirelessly and continuously , to improve that product year after year. Focus on aspects that cannot be copied or imitated. In the iPhone's case, those are things such as custom chips, superior hardware components and manufacturing techniques, software frameworks decades in the making, a culture that prioritizes great design, and an ever-expanding ecosystem that keeps customers in the flock by making them happy . Build a luxury resort they don't want to leave, not a prison they can't leave.

Don't prioritize being first or being cheapest. Prioritize being the best. That's a simple strategy. It's the execution that's hard as hell.

Yes, a box cutter/utility knife that costs about $100. A $100 tool to replace the sort of disposable thing that costs like a $1 a pop. entry.summary: I don't know how many people are going to be irritated, if not downright angry, about this switch, but it's going to be a *lot* more people than most “*the iPhone should have already switched to USB-C*” proponents expect.
entry.content:
Tim Hardwick, writing for MacRumors :

Apple may offer a USB-C data transfer accessory cable for iPhone 15 Pro models that is capable of Thunderbolt or USB4 speeds of up to 40Gbps. That is the latest claim made by Kosutami , who posted details of the cable on Twitter (now X). According to the leaker, the length of the cable is 0.8 meters, which is shorter than Apple's existing Thunderbolt 4 Pro cable (1.8m), and it is said to support charging up to 150W. Apple will allegedly sell the cable separately.

Lest you think it nickel-and-dime-y for Apple to sell a Thunderbolt 4 cable separately, note that Thunderbolt 4 cables are expensive . Apple currently sells two : the 1.8m one costs $129, and the 3m one costs $159. I bought a 0.8m one made by Razor last year, with very similar feel and quality to Apple's, that Amazon currently sells for $46 . (That's a make-me-rich affiliate link, if you're in the market for a Thunderbolt 4 cable.) A 1m Thunderbolt cable from Monoprice (rubber, not braided) costs $30 . Apple's own 0.8m Thunderbolt 3 cable costs $39. I'm guessing this new 0.8m Thunderbolt 4 cable from Apple will cost $99. It'd be downright silly for Apple to include an expensive (and thick, stiff, and short) cable like that with every iPhone 15 Pro.

The reason to even offer such a cable, and to offer Thunderbolt 4 performance on the phones, is for data transfer, specifically video. The single biggest frustration regarding iPhones sticking with Lightning until this year is that 4K video files are very large, but USB 2.0 data transfer is very slow. iPhones have been capable of shooting 4K video since the 6S models in 2015, and as their image quality has improved each year, the data transfer limitations of Lightning has seemed more and more incongruous. 1

I ran into this twice, when we used iPhones to shoot the COVID-era episodes of The Talk Show Remote From WWDC in 2020 and 2021 . The footage looked great, but it took hours to transfer it off the phones. Heretofore, iPhones have offered pro-quality video cameras limited to decidedly consumer-level data transfer rates.

Speaking of “pro”, though, faster data transfer speeds might literally be capital-P Pro features this year. Hardwick continues:

Speculation therefore remains rife about the USB-C port capabilities of the iPhone 15 lineup, and nothing is certain beyond the switch from Lightning. Rumors suggest the cables supplied in iPhone 15 boxes are limited to USB 2.0 data transfer speeds at a rate of 480 MBps, which is the same as Lightning.

In contrast, the iPhone 15 Pro models are expected to be supplied with cables capable of USB 3.2 or Thunderbolt 3 transfer speeds, as per Kuo's original claim. Images from ChargerLab suggest that some iPhone 15 models will include a Thunderbolt/USB 4 retimer chip, seemingly confirming the rumor of higher-speed data transfer for the Pro models.

Each iPhone 15 will include a braided USB-C charging cable in the box that is thicker (ie more durable) and 50% longer than the Lightning cable that comes with current iPhone models, according to reports . The cables are also rumored to be color-matched to possible new iPhone colors , coming in at least black, white, yellow, blue, and orange.

Even most Pro-model iPhone buyers never transfer data over a cable, so differentiating the iPhone 15 Pro models from the non-pro ones in this way feels fair. Including color-matched braided cables with all new models would be a nice touch (and lines up with other recent products, like the M1 iMacs and M2 MacBook Airs, that ship with color-matched braided cables). But the fact that some of these phones (the non-pro ones) might support only USB 2 speeds (480 Mbps), while others (the Pro models) will support up to Thunderbolt 4 (40 Gbps — roughly 80× faster), yet all the ports and cable connectors will look the same to the naked eye, only goes to show just how confusing “USB-C” is. Glenn Fleishman's headline from 2021 remains as apt as ever: “ USBefuddled: Untangling the Rat's Nest of USB-C Standards and Cables ”.

While I'm writing about the switch to USB-C, let me make a prediction how this will be received when it's officially announced in two weeks. The small number of filmmakers who shoot using iPhones (small compared to the aggregate number of iPhone users overall) will rejoice. The larger number of nerds, and even semi-nerds, who travel with multiple computing devices and just want USB-C charging connectors on all them will be happy. But the vast silent majority of normal iPhone users? I think there's going to be a backlash that most USB-C proponents don't see coming, premised on accusations that this switch is a money grab from Apple to get people to replace all their Lightning cables with new $30 USB-C cables from the Apple Store .

You , dear reader, of course know that USB-C is an industry standard and you can buy high-quality cables from stores other than Apple. I don't think everyone knows that. And even those who will buy their new USB-C charging cables from companies other than Apple are likely to grouse about the need to buy new cables at all.

When Apple switched from the 30-pin iPod connector to Lightning with the iPhone 5 in 2012, there was a lot of grousing. And that was a port switch where you could easily see how much better the new one was. (The old 30-pin connector and port really do look absurd to modern eyes.) At a glance USB-C doesn't look any better than and barely different from Lightning. My gut feeling is that not much has changed since 2012 on the “new iPhone connector” front, other than the fact that there are, quite literally, over a billion more iPhone users today than then, and thus perhaps billions of extant Lightning cables in use. Typical users put more value on being able to just keep using the old cables (and chargers) they already have 2 — at their bedsides, in their kitchens, on their desks, in their cars, in their backpacks and purses — than reducing the number of different types of cables they need in their lives.

I don't know how many people are going to be irritated, if not downright angry, about this switch, but it's going to be a lot more people 3 than most “ the iPhone should have already switched to USB-C ” proponents expect. Me, I'll gladly take the vastly-improved data transfer speeds. But I won't be the one answering the phone at 1-800-MY-APPLE.

  1. Steven Soderbergh shot the feature film Unsane using iPhone 7's in 2017 . It looks great — deliberately grainy, in a throwback 16mm film way — but it boggles the mind to consider how much time they spent waiting for footage to transfer off the iPhones. ↩︎

  2. It's worth noting that many iPhone users will be able to keep using their existing charging cables — if they've been using MagSafe instead of Lightning. I think this is the single biggest reason Apple has waited so long to switch the iPhone to USB-C. (The iPad Pros switched from Lightning five years ago.) I think they wanted to introduce MagSafe first, let people accumulate a few MagSafe cables in the places where they charge their iPhones, and then switch from Lightning to USB-C. Three years of iPhones (12, 13, 14) have already had MagSafe, so that's about an average upgrade cycle for most users. But anecdotally, the normals in my family don't use MagSafe, they use Lightning, probably because the cables are cheaper. ↩︎︎

  3. And a lot more clickbait-y “Look What Apple Is Forcing iPhone Users to Buy” headlines. ↩︎︎

entry.title: Adobe Co-Founder John Warnock Dies at 82
entry.content:
Clay Risen, reporting for The New York Times:

John Warnock, a founder of Adobe Systems whose innovations in computer graphics, including the ubiquitous PDF, made possible today's visually rich digital experiences, died on Aug. 19 at his home in Los Altos, Calif. He was 82.

The cause was pancreatic cancer, Adobe, which Dr. Warnock started in 1982 with Chuck Geschke, said in a statement.

It was just a month ago that pancreatic cancer took Kevin Mitnick, and I remarked on how many people this specific cancer has taken of late.

Until Dr. Warnock and Adobe came along, desktop printing was an arduous, expensive and unsatisfying endeavor. Users relied on either a screechy dot-matrix printer, with its pixelated text, or a specialized typesetting machine, which could cost $10,000 and take up most of a room.

Dr. Warnock developed protocols that came loaded into desktop printers themselves, and that accurately rendered what a computer sent them. Adobe's first such protocol, PostScript, went into Apple's revolutionary LaserWriter, released in 1985, and within a few years it was the industry standard.

PostScript, licensed to hundreds of software and hardware companies, helped make Adobe rich. But the company was largely unknown to the public until 1993, when it released Acrobat, a program designed to render and read files in what it called a Portable Document Format, or PDF.

PDF was an enormous breakthrough, and is more relevant today than ever. A true document format for the ages. But Adobe was well on its way before 1993. Photoshop 1.0 launched in early 1990 . They began shipping their library of original PostScript fonts and the essential Adobe Type Manager software in 1989. And Illustrator 1.0 launched back in 1987, shipping with this video tour demonstrated by Warnock himself .

Warnock and Geschke understood what Steve Jobs often preached: technology alone was not enough. PostScript was — and remains ! — excellent technology. But it was not a product. The LaserWriter was a product. You hooked it up, went to File → Print in any application, and you got professional-grade 300 DPI output with no technical expertise necessary. It was as easy to print high-quality output on a LaserWriter as it was to print junk output on a slow, noisy dot-matrix printer. That was a product.

And Illustrator turned PostScript from a rather difficult but highly-capable programming language into a tool designed for use by artists. They didn't just make a nice code editor for writing PostScript. They created an app that presented a visual framework in which you directly manipulated shapes, lines, and curves as objects. Even expert Illustrator users were never exposed to PostScript directly. The Illustrator metaphor was a complete encapsulation . That too was a product, and Illustrator remains an essential tool. If Warnock and Geschke had been satisfied merely with shipping great technology alone, Adobe Systems would be a nearly forgotten Silicon Valley footnote. Instead, they pushed to make Adobe the great tool-making product company we know today.

★

entry.title: 'Giving Up the iPad-Only Travel Dream'
entry.content:
Jason Snell, writing at Six Colors:

In the battle between iPad and Mac, I'm a longtime member of Team Both — I use my Mac most of the day at my desk, but when I write elsewhere in the house or backyard, I switch to an iPad Pro in the Magic Keyboard case. And that iPad (in a regular case) is my primary computing device when I'm not in work mode.

I'm not at all ready to declare the “use iPad to get work done” experiment dead. With the forthcoming release of iPadOS 17, Stage Manager has thrown in a bunch of improvements that suggest the iPad's progression to more functional status continues, albeit at a pace that's a bit too slow for my liking.

But here I sit at my mother's dining room table, typing on a MacBook Air. Something has changed in my approach to travel, and I'm trying to understand just what it is and what it tells me about the trajectory of the iPad as a productivity tool.

I've written at length , multiple times, about my decidedly mixed feelings regarding the iPad — most stridently in January 2020, in a piece titled “ The iPad Awkwardly Turns 10 ”. Stage Manager is the biggest change to the iPad interface since I wrote that, and its existence certainly helps on that “power user” front. (And Stage Manager sees some nice improvements in this year's iPadOS 17.) But for me personally, I continue to find that I'm most productive when I spend my working time in front of my Mac. Gobs of people thrive using their iPads for writing and other creative endeavors. But I know I'm best off, productivity-wise, using my iPad basically as a single-tasking consumption device for long-form reading and video watching.

The reason this topic remains evergreen is that I want to use my iPad more. There's something ineffable about it. It's a thrill when I use my iPad to do something that an iPad is actually best at. I honestly think I'd be more productive if I owned no iPad at all, yet I keep trying to find ways to use it more.

So when I travel, it's never a question whether I'll pack my MacBook Pro. Even if I don't plan or want to work during a particular trip, the one-man-show nature of Daring Fireball means I feel that I need to be able to. (I was on a family vacation, preparing to head to dinner, when this news broke 12 years ago yesterday .) The question is whether I even pack my iPad Pro at all, or just go it alone with iPhone and Mac. When I'm packing, I generally wind up tossing the iPad in my bag, thinking I'll miss it if I don't. But when I do just leave the iPad at home, I don't miss it. It's confounding, though, because I'm going on a trip next week and I bet I'll take my damn iPad.

entry.summary: What will actually happen, I believe, is that E2EE messaging platforms like WhatsApp (overwhelmingly popular in the UK), Signal, and iMessage *will stop working and be pulled from app stores in the UK*, full stop. The UK seems to think it's a bluff;我不。
entry.content:
Ioannis Kouvakas, writing for Just Security :

While the proposal does not specify what technical changes would require notification, these may include changes in the architecture of software that would interfere with the UK's current surveillance powers. As a result, an operator of a messaging service wishing to introduce an advanced security feature would now have to first let the Home Office know in advance. Device manufacturers would likely also have to notify the government before making available important security updates that fix known vulnerabilities and keep devices secure . Accordingly, the Secretary of State, upon receiving such an advance notice, could now request operators to, for instance, abstain from patching security gaps to allow the government to maintain access for surveillance purposes.

This is exactly where I've thought, for months, that the United Kingdom is heading with this legislation, but it's still shocking to see it described so starkly. It's like watching someone drive toward a cliff, and warning people, “ Hey, I think these guys are driving right toward that cliff ” — and yet I'm still taken aback to see them drive off the cliff.

It's a complete fantasy that E2EE can be toggled like a light switch and still allow messages to be delivered. The end-to-end encryption isn't a sugar coating, some sort of extra layer of protection — it's fundamental to the messaging protocols themselves. It has to be, when you think about it. If it were possible for, say, Signal, to silently disable E2EE but still have messages go through, how could users ever trust the service? You could neither trust that what you were sending would be delivered securely, nor that what you received wasn't intercepted by an interloper. There's an explicit guarantee with all of these E2EE messaging platforms that messages can only go through securely . Removing E2EE wouldn't require some mere tweak to the protocols, it would require replacing the protocols entirely (with inherently insecure ones).

And the notion that security updates, for every user in the world, would need the approval of the UK Home Office just to make sure the patches weren't closing vulnerabilities that the government itself is exploiting — it boggles the mind. Even if the UK were the only country in the world to pass such a law, it would be madness, but what happens when other countries follow?

As I see it, the most likely outcome is that the UK passes the law, thinking that the grave concerns conveyed to them by the messaging services are overblown. That the platform providers are saying they can't comply but they really just mean they don't want to comply because it's just difficult, not impossible. And when it becomes law, the platforms will hand it off to the nerds, the nerds will nerd harder, and boom, the platforms will fall into compliance with this law. That's what they think will happen. What will actually happen, I believe, is that E2EE messaging platforms like WhatsApp (overwhelmingly popular in the UK), Signal, and iMessage will stop working and be pulled from app stores in the UK , full stop. The UK seems to think it's a bluff;我不。

Perhaps the argument — as made by Kouvakas — that these changes would run afoul of international law will resonate with the UK in a way that technical arguments, thus far, have not.
